mdx.body:
So first of all, **why**? I've been around the sun a few times at this point and I've learned a lot
in my short time as a SWE lad (6.5 years as of writing this). Much of what I've learned was from
others, both in person and through the internet. What I want to do with this blog is to give back a
bit and document some of the problems that I've solved or found interesting.

We've all been there: it's 12:30am and you still can't find the answer that you're looking for.
CrapGPT is running in circles. You rearrange your search terms _just a tad_ and the search ghouls
serve up some different results. Some you've clicked on, some you haven't. One that you haven't
clicked on yet has generic domain like github.io. Maybe it's a blog? You decide to enter and yes! A
blog! The more you read, the more you think you've got a lead on the issue. Does it have a ton of
fluff? Maybe. Does the blog post solve your issue? No, but it points you in a direction finally that
gives you a different error. That's the kind of tech blog I want to have.

# Sooooo... how?

There are some technologies that I know from my time as a SWE: React and Markdown. I _really_ like
Markdown, and so many applications that I use allow for Markdown so being able to write in Markdown
is a strict requirement. React I can take it or leave it, but I certainly don't want to write
content in React. Finally, I would like to learn something new.

Those very loose requirements leave a few (non-exhaustive) options:

- [Eleventy](https://www.11ty.dev/)
  - Easy to set up
  - Easy to add content
  - Styled with themes
- [Gatsby](https://www.gatsbyjs.com/)
  - Not easy to set up, requires build system
  - Easy to add content once system is in place
  - Can by styled with tailwindcss
- [Obsidian Publish](https://obsidian.md/publish)
  - Easy to set up
  - Easy to add content
  - Costs $8 a month as of writing this, subject to pricing changes
- [Quartz](https://quartz.jzhao.xyz/)
  - Easy to set up
  - Easy to add content
  - Familiar Obsidian flows

With those options being considered, it seems like Eleventy or Quartz are the winners. They are! But
naturally, I went with the most difficult option purely to build and learn something: Gatsby.

### Gatsby stack

If you're not familiar with how Gatsby works, it's basically just a static React frontend that uses
GraphQL to source content. That content is then built into React components. It supports a vast
plugin ecosystem that allows for adding support to all sorts of features.

As of writing this post, my Gatsby setup includes:

- MDX (markdown, but support for inline React components)
- Code syntax highlighting via [prismjs](https://github.com/PrismJS/prism#readme)
- [Mermaid graph support](https://github.com/mermaid-js/mermaid#readme)
- [Tailwind CSS](https://tailwindcss.com)
- Typescript
- UI components from [shadcn](https://ui.shadcn.com/)

Was it easy to set up? No, BUT I did learn quite a bit about some things I have never used before
like shadcn and tailwind, so I don't feel bad about these choices.

## Where's the boilerplate?

I haven't got any, sorry. I call this the "learn and cry" stack. One day maybe I'll put up a base
project template somewhere, but today is not that day. My recommendation for using a similar setup
as mine is to work through the issues yourself. If you want a good to go setup, then I suggest some
of the other options above.

I also have a weird setup in that I want to have two blogs essentially. I want to be able to post
about hobbies and other things in life that are not tech related. You know, things to show your
friends and family that indicate that I'm doing something other than staring at my laptop all during
working hours and then going home and doing the same thing until I go to bed.

My abnormal setup is mine and mine alone!! Just kidding, as I was writing this, I got side-tracked
and pushed up the template, but modified to not be two pieces. Here it is:
[gatsby-mdx-ts-tailwind-template](https://github.com/Balake/gatsby-mdx-ts-tailwind-template). This
is probably the best way for me to share rather than too many code snippets here. As a proof that I
_can_ do code snippets though, here's one! This is the auto generation of posts which are then
accessible via their respective links:

```typescript
export const createPages: GatsbyNode["createPages"] = async ({ graphql, actions, reporter }) => {
  const result = await graphql<{
    posts: { nodes: Post[] };
  }>(`
    query Posts {
      posts: allMdx(
        filter: { internal: { contentFilePath: { regex: "/posts/" } } }
        sort: { frontmatter: { date: DESC } }
      ) {
        nodes {
          frontmatter {
            title
            date
          }
          internal {
            contentFilePath
          }
          id
        }
      }
    }
  `);

  if (result.errors) {
    reporter.panicOnBuild("Error loading MDX result", result.errors);
  }
  if (!result.data) {
    reporter.panicOnBuild("No MDX result data", result.errors);
    return;
  }
  const posts = result.data.posts;

  posts.nodes.forEach((node) => {
    actions.createPage({
      path: getSlug(node.internal.contentFilePath),
      component: `${path.resolve("./templates/post.tsx")}?__contentFilePath=${
        node.internal.contentFilePath
      }`,
      context: {
        id: node.id,
      },
    });
  });
};
```

## Deployment

Haven't actually done this yet, but I think I can just
[deploy to Github pages](https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/how-to/previews-deploys-hosting/how-gatsby-works-with-github-pages/),
so that's what I'm going to attempt to do. If you're reading this, that means I succeeded in
deployment somehow.

Update: deployment success. I was able to also get auto deploys working! I ran into some issues with
using a modern version of `yarn`, but was able to get around it. Below is the snippet for my
automatic deployments:

```yaml
name: Gatsby Publish

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]

jobs:
  deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3

      # Setup Node.js (LTS)
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: "lts/*"

      # Enable Corepack for Yarn Plug'n'Play and use project yarn version
      - name: Enable Corepack and Use Project Yarn Version
        run: |
          corepack enable
          corepack prepare yarn@stable --activate
          yarn --version

      # Deploy using Gatsby GH Pages Action
      - uses: enriikke/gatsby-gh-pages-action@v2
        with:
          access-token: ${{ secrets.ACCESS_TOKEN }}
          deploy-branch: main
          deploy-repo: "balake.github.io"
```

# What's next?

My plan is to get my [everything else namespace](/blog/everything-else) up and running. I have some
more ideas on what I want to write for this tech namespace as well.

Stay tuned!

\- Balake, blog beginner
